section.p: Over the past few years, research carried out at large-scale materials science facilities in the USA and elsewhere has undergone a phase transition that affected its character and culture. Research cultures at these facilities now resemble ecosystems, comprising of complex and evolving interactions between individuals, institutions, and the overall research environment. The outcome of this phase transition, which has been gradual and building since the 1980s, is known as the New (or Ecologic) Big Science [Crease, R. and Westfall, C. (2016). The new big science. Physics Today, 69: 30–6]. In this article, we describe this phase transition, review the practical challenges that it poses for historians, review some potential digital tools that might respond to these challenges, and then assess the theoretical implications posed by “database history’.

div.p: Over the past few years, research carried out at large-scale materials science facilities in the USA and elsewhere has undergone a phase transition that affected its character and culture. Research cultures at these facilities now resemble ecosystems, comprising complex and evolving interactions between individuals, institutions, and the overall research environment.

The outcome of this phase transition, which has been gradual and building since the 1980s, is known as the New (or Ecologic) Big Science (Crease and Westfall 2016). In this article, we describe this phase transition, review the practical challenges that it poses for historians, review some potential digital tools that might respond to these challenges, and then assess the theoretical implications posed by ‘database history’.

What we might call the Old Big Science was born, starting after the Second World War, with the creation of national laboratories, whose existence was justified by the construction and management of instruments too big for any single university to build. By the 1960s, such laboratories hosted large instruments, such as accelerators and research reactors, for the benefit of a broad spectrum of national and international researchers. Such laboratories always included a mixture of smaller, lower profile facilities that included instruments for materials science research, but these were parasitic on the principal function of the laboratory: to make it possible to stage the main basic research function at large scales. The primary dynamic of the Old Big Science was that the scale of its premier high-energy physics projects—instruments, collaborations, and the time-scale that projects followed—increased rapidly.

Starting in the 1980s, however, materials science facilities began replacing high-energy accelerators as the marquee projects at national laboratories. The reasons for this are complex and overdetermined, and include the end of the Cold War, increasing attention to materials science as a way to boost national competitiveness, and the growing scale of high-energy physics projects. One landmark event in this transition occurred in 1993, with the cancellation of the Superconducting Supercollider, which left the USA without a forefront high-energy physics accelerator. After this cancellation, the US national laboratories had to find other ways to justify their existence, which they did through a new emphasis on materials science.

Yet, materials science research has a very different character from high-energy research. In the New Big Science, instruments and collaborations do not get bigger and bigger; instead, the research ecosystem grows more complicated. That ecosystem involves more and more fields (especially biomedical fields) making use of national laboratories, a wider variety of instruments, more connections between seemingly disparate research programs, and a faster turnover of programs. The character of the research ecosystem is different and changes more rapidly.

In order to show exactly why the New Big Science presents, for historians of science, a distinctively complex object of research, we might briefly describe several specific features of research in the New Big Science that set it off from the Old Big Science:

blockquote.p: One is the integration of an industrial presence from the beginning in many of the research projects. Industries sometimes build instruments that are transported to and installed at materials science facilities, and then moved to other facilities. Instruments of Old Big Science facilities generally stayed put.

div.p: Another feature is the scope and complexity of the interdisciplinary networks, which can simultaneously involve several national labs, several universities, and several industries. Moreover, these research networks are what we might call octopoidal, in that a single research project can have tentacles in many beamlines at one or more facilities, and a single beamline can be connected to numerous research projects.

The New Big Science also tends to generate quasi-independent subfacilities that themselves support networks with the above properties. Among other complexities that this causes, this decentralization of the research networks in the New Big Science makes it harder to impose and enforce regulations, a state of affairs that threatens to undermine the entire enterprise of effective ethics and safety regulation.

The formation of knowledge in this research culture is also different. Instead of research projects addressing single puzzles, materials scientists often work to pull together a mosaic of properties whose focus may change rapidly with the properties of the materials being produced.

Finally, there are more intangible differences in the research culture at materials science facilities. For example, while researchers at large accelerators are forced to wait patiently when the machine breaks down, those at materials science facilities are not; they are more mobile, and consequently are far more impatient with shutdowns.

This description brings us to the focus of this article: the challenges of telling stories about such a research ecosystem, and the opportunities that specific digital tools and methods offer for meeting such challenges. Our project, the National Synchrotron Light Source (NSLS) Digital Archive, is a response to the practical challenges this research culture poses for historians, replacing the limitations of narrative history with the potential scope and flexibility of database history. This article uses the categorizing imperative in database design as an occasion to consider, from the distinctive perspective of the history of science, the relationship between database design and the domain expertise of the historian. In particular, we are interested in the functional potential, in this realm of tool design, of the humanistic concepts of narrative and performance.

Consider the traditional methods for investigating the research ecosystem at a science facility. The traditional tools that a historian can bring to such a research object are diverse but narrow; confined to the length of a book or article, he must choose one or a few currents in the full ecosystem on which to focus, a choice that will define her habitus in the field of history and direct the significance claims he makes for his object. For example, he might choose to track a machine’s operational history: when the device was shut down for maintenance, repairs, and upgrades; what was done (and where) during these shutdowns—what insertion devices were installed, and what modifications were made to beam monitoring systems, vacuum chambers, and power supplies—and what differences these changes made to the key parameters of the machine, such as amps and brightness, when it came back on. Alternatively, he might track the machine’s administrative history: who the directors and principal administrators were. Or he might track its functional history: what collaborations worked at which holes with what instruments in which fields. She might choose to focus on markers of excellence such as patents, prizes, participating research teams (PRTs), cooperative research and development agreements (CRADAs), educational programs (for example, high school and summer school programs, undergraduate and graduate theses served, Westinghouse awards won), or major awards such as the prestigious ‘R&D 100’ awards for technological achievement that Research and Development magazine confers. And this is only the beginning; he could focus on the publications associated with each port or research program; the personnel associated with each port or research program; the instruments associated with each port or research program, and when they were built, rebuilt, or replaced; the particular subfields that have been associated with which specific ports or research programs; the connections between research programs, ports at the NSLS, and instruments elsewhere at the lab or at other facilities; the funding, in the form of prizes, grants, and other funding sources, associated with work associated with each port or research program; the industries associated with each port or research program; the historical map of research programs at the NSLS, how long they lasted, and how they were funded; or the applications of research findings.

It is our argument here, however, that narratives and lists of this kind are of little value unless they are connected with each other. So essential is interconnectedness to the New Big Science that traditional historical methods, which must follow only a few threads at a time, cannot adequately account for the functioning of this research ecosystem nor explain its achievements. This mode of practicing science can only be fully understood if connectivity and interdependence are placed in the foreground of the historian’s attention. In the old Big Science, the size and scale of facilities and the experiments at them grew bigger and bigger, but it was still possible to tell stories in a more or less linear fashion. One could talk about (for instance) a machine’s operational history or its administrative history, and one could so talk in terms of relatively linear stories, though the picture of the facility or laboratory could be made more complex by interweaving such stories. (Furthermore, the historian is often justified in telling linear stories of Big Science experiments because such experiments often became institutions themselves, producing strings of related experiments of long duration that have been called ‘experimental strings’.) (Hoddeson et al. 2011).

In the New Big Science, this approach loses its viability. A new complexity has arisen in the research process that springs not so much from an increased size and scale of facilities and instruments but from a transformed research environment. In the new era of materials science, the experiments don’t come in strings; they are smaller, more numerous, and have more links with each other and with instruments, beam lines, industries, labs, funders, fields, and collaborators. Moreover, the history of any one aspect of research relies, to a degree not seen in earlier systems of knowledge production, on the evolution of an entire ecologic environment. In a research ecosystem this complicated and even basic and traditional questions are difficult to answer. For instance, what biological science has happened at materials science facilities, and how has this science evolved? More detailed questions are still more difficult to answer: what were the connections between specific kinds of biological research, such as protein structure determination, and other fields such as physics, chemistry, and engineering, and how did these connections evolve? What instruments were shared across fields? What fields were shared across instruments? How did the overall research ecosystem change from, say 1987 to 1997 to 2007? How have these connections evolved over time, and how are they related to the evolution of broader social concerns about health, epidemics, and so forth? These are interesting and important questions—not just to science historians but also to scientists, administrators, funding agencies, and policy makers.

The extent and complexity of these links would make new tools necessary even to tell traditional linear stories. The problem is not only the size of the data set but also the complexity of interactions among elements. More fields and subfields make use of materials science facilities. These facilities support a wider variety of instruments, more connections between seemingly disparate research programs, a broader spectrum of users, and they experience a faster turnover of programs. Research cultures at large-scale facilities now resemble ecosystems, comprising complex and evolving interactions between individuals, institutions, and the overall research environment. How can we track key changes in that ecosystem, and how can we bring to bear on this history research methods that will enable us to find new and unexpected kinds of changes?

As it happens, we, too, live at a moment characterized by transformation in our forms of knowledge production defined, in part, by new tools that facilitate the rethinking of research objects in terms of connections and relationships. In particular, these tools include the relational database and a growing humanistic concern with database use, an orientation that new media scholars have begun to address as database thinking.

The best way to introduce the specific challenges of database thinking is to outline the particulars of our current project, which takes as its basis the NSLS. The NSLS was a historic site for groundbreaking research in materials science from 1982 to 2014; during that time, it was one of the world’s most widely used scientific facilities. The NSLS is anchored in Brookhaven National Laboratory, is managed on behalf of the US Department of Energy (DOE) by Brookhaven Science Associates, of which our home institution of Stony Brook University is a partner. The machine spins electrons in a circle so that they give off light (two circles, one for X-ray light and the other for ultraviolet light), and then reaps the light through several dozen ports. At each port, instruments shape the light so that it can be put to a range of tasks, such as studying materials via electromagnetic radiation.

In terms of research, the NSLS is one of the most productive and diverse instruments ever built. In more than three decades of operation, it served over 57,000 users from laboratories, universities, and industry. Their work resulted in 17,000 publications, 7,000 successfully identified protein crystal structures, and two Nobel Prizes. As an avatar of the New Big Science and a model of its distinctive ecosystem, the NSLS is ideal. The facility constitutes a single bounded entity with a material existence and a bounded period of operation. (We ended the period of study at 2014 because the old machine was torn down and replaced by a newer machine with more sophisticated instruments.) The facility has also produced a rich and deep trove of records for us to work with. Brookhaven National Laboratory issues annual reports that supply information about each program of research. The archives of the NSLS Department hold a range of files that include copies of the department’s annual reports. The NSLS also had to report on itself to its sponsoring agency, the DOE, and we can access those reports and presentations to DOE review panels. We can also consult the ‘Brookhaven Lectures’, given once a month, in which scientists report on their work; these were printed (in the early days), then audio-recorded (about 20 years ago), and are now video-recorded. Finally, one of us (Robert Crease) has conducted a set of oral interviews with the NSLS founders and some of its key researchers, and is prepared to do more. These provide an invaluable source of information on the research ecology at the NSLS. The facility serves for us as analogous to an ecologist’s quadrat, or tool used to isolate a representative region in which to analyze an ecosystem.

The vast number of experiments that took place at the NSLS, and the vast amount of data that it produced during a history that encompassed many changing disciplines, make it nearly impossible to gain a comprehensive global view of the knowledge production that took place at this facility. Traditional historical methods and linear narratives fail to capture precisely the elements that demand new exploration. We are therefore collaborating to develop a new kind of digital tool to capture the history of this research. This project will comprise a digital archive to obtain a history of the NSLS, the main component of which will be a relational database that allows for a wide range of forms of query and analysis. We plan to build the database using open-source, web-standard technologies, which will foster the tool’s sustainability and make it easier for users to export data for their own purposes. Our hope is that the data associated with the NSLS will present the public with an appealing sandbox of information about scientific activity. Based on the success of data visualization as a genre and the visualizations that members of the public have made with, for instance, openly available government data, we are confident that many people will take up the opportunity to ‘play around’ with data about the history of the New Big Science. [Although we have not yet designed the archive’s application programming interface (API), which will be implemented during the second phase of our project—see below—one of our primary tools for building interactive features of the archive will likely be d3.js, a JavaScript library that enables programmers to create data visualizations to be viewed in a web browser.]

The design of the archive reflects a dual interest in academic study and public education: making use of interactive features will give the task of exploring scientific activity a playful, game-like aspect for members of the public (who may range from degree holders to high school science students). The archive will not only support the needs of scholars, but it will also help the general public to see how government funding translates into large-scale scientific enterprises.

We are building iteratively, following a phased plan, which enables us to test data models as we go and make changes easily. At present, we are in the first phase, which comprises data capture: Jamie Folsom, VP for Development with Performant software, and formerly lead web applications developer for MIT’s digital humanities lab, has built a basic database platform using Ruby on Rails, a web application framework. We are currently populating the database with data, having started with a small set of categories that we can expand as needed: administrators, funding, institutions, instruments, ports, publications, research programs, scientists, scientific disciplines, and technicians.

We chose these initial models with an eye to the historical ‘layers’ that we want the NSLS Archive to accommodate––instruments, technicians: the history of the physical instrument itself, which was constantly changing and being improved; administrators: the changing leaders and other administrators of the machine; ports, instruments: what happened at each port or ‘hole’; the instruments that were built, rebuilt, or changed at each; research programs, scientists, scientific discipline, funding: the changing research programs at each hole; publications: the papers published. Many of these categories allow for further granularity, for example, descriptions of the types of research being done at the facility, which scale from the general (e.g., materials science) to the specific (the study of defects in single-crystal materials) to the unique (‘Observation of Growth Defects in GaInSb Single Crystal by Synchrotron White Beam X-Ray Topography’).1

In the project’s upcoming second phase, we will build a web-accessible API that will make the data available in standard formats so that as wide a range of researchers as possible can use it.2 We will also build search functionalities for the archive so that researchers can find information more easily. Although we are using a normalized relational database for the data entry phase, we will use the API to expose the resulting dataset in denormalized and aggregated forms that are well suited for analysis. That is, while the data models we develop during the data entry phase will be suited for rapid and accurate capture of information, the API will expose the resulting data in formats and structures that are maximally useful for researchers.

The API will allow programmers to use any language or toolset they are comfortable with. We anticipate that many programmers will use JavaScript, and frameworks written in Javascript, such as d3.js, the most well-established library for data visualization in web browsers. Data will be returned as JSON, a standard format that will enable researchers with programming experience in a range of languages to work with the data on their own.

Before we can build the API, however, we need to finish populating the database with a sufficiently representative quantity and range of data. Our iterative development plan reflects the undiscovered histories that we are working with: we are not yet sure exactly what is in the data. As we enter new troves of data into the database, we can refine and improve the data model that we use to structure the database until we find a model that works just right for the entire corpus.

Similarly, our choice of specific tools or programming languages as we move the project forward will depend on the questions that we determine to be most worth asking and, by extension, the research paradigms that we bring to the subject matter. (See the discussion on ‘performance’ below.) For example, while building the API, we will likely choose between two common types of APIs, REST (representational state transfer) and a newer type, GraphQL. Choosing the latter would reflect a recognition that we want to be able to ask questions, which can only be answered by fetching data from many different parts of the dataset. For example, ‘What are the relationships between two domains as measured by researchers doing work in both of those domains?’ GraphQL APIs allow programmers to make requests for those kinds of ‘compound’ data structures more easily than REST.

Thus, the NSLS Digital Archive engages with pressing challenges in current humanities practice in two dimensions. The first dimension is concerned with the history of science: as we have discussed, the project aims to demonstrate that new kinds of digital tools can archive and present complex changing patterns of research and configurations of scientific infrastructure. Digital tools have the potential to help significantly with this challenge by storing, integrating, and imaging the large amounts of information needed to answer the questions we may ask of a complex ecologic environment. As the above discussion suggests, digital tools also have the potential, in the course of their creation, to force scholars to confront their own research paradigms as structures of opportunity and constraint, as when data models are developed iteratively in conversation with scholars’ framing of questions and explorations of the archive.

However, these tools also pose a new set of problems. The second dimension, to which we would like now to turn, concerns the relationship between the domain expertise of the historian and the design of a historical database. As the creation of historical databases becomes an increasingly common practice, particularly in response to the need to use digital methods to explore complex research objects, we have a growing need to articulate principles for the design of digital tools that will support the kinds of analysis and discovery that we have traditionally valued as historians. For example, tools for the curation of large data sets can allow researchers to sift through unprecedented quantities of information, but they can also overwhelm researchers by generating meaningless information and insignificant patterns. For the researcher who hopes to create a digital artifact that constitutes, in itself, an evaluable contribution to his field, the problem of how to supply a database with the right sample of information becomes a challenge with terms rather different from what most archivists confront.3 And while one benefit of using databases is supposed to be freedom from the limitations of received ideas—a notion that Wired magazine memorably publicized by heralding big data as ‘the end of theory’—scholars such as Underwood (2014) have reminded us that our digital research tools rely, however invisibly, on a range of preexisting narratives and assumptions. Our digital tools should be kept in service of focused historical inquiry, but also used flexibly enough to allow the researcher to encounter surprises. As we will show, this is no easy task.

The practical problem at the core of this paper—the problem, given the necessity of using database systems to capture the history of the New Big Science, of how to build a database that historians can as a genuine research tool and does not simply illustrate information that’s already encoded in the database—overlaps with the general problem of ‘database history’ as a genre.4 As we have just outlined, the problem in historiography that the new archive is designed to address lies in the fixed and linear structure narrative of most historical narratives. The research that facilities such as the NSLS are designed to support is too diverse, too massive, and too indeterminate with respect to figure and ground, ‘with thousands of projects running simultaneously over more than three decades’, to reward such traditional forms of historical storytelling. In its place, we propose to create an online database that will make available papers and historical data relating to the NSLS for use by historians, journalists, policy makers, and members of the lay public, from which a variety of histories can emerge. This leads, however, to a question about the relationship between databases and historical narrative: would the architecture of a web platform and a user interface necessarily restrict, guide, predetermine, or overwhelm the possible storylines that users are able to develop using the tools and functionality of the archive?

According to classical narratology, historical narratives that take the form of written text traditionally appear as a chronological chain of events in which certain themes and topics take prominence, and others fall away. A historian may choose which genre of narrative to use for his history—and, depending on his training, he may choose to favor certain types of evidence or patterns of argument within that narrative—but in general, he must use a narrative genre. (Narratology lists four classical types of narrative genre: romance, in which the protagonist struggles against the constraints of the world and ultimately transcends them; tragedy, in which the protagonist struggles against the constraints of the world and ultimately loses; comedy, in which the world of constraint and the world of the spirit are ultimately shown to be in harmony; and satire, which emphasizes the impossibility of making sense of the world using a structuring narrative.) (White 1973).

From the relatively new genre of the historical database, then, two questions arise. First: Does the design of a database, whether in the configuration of the user interface, the selection of its contents, or the indexes that manage its workings, limit the stories that emerge from its contents in a way that would be recognizable to a narratologist? As one wag has asked: could there be such a thing as a tragic database; a satirical database? The second question is: Does the involvement of human agents in managing this database limit or predetermine the uses that will be made of its contents? This question regards the database as an analog not to a book but to a journal such as Annales, Representations, or Année Sociologique, which not only curated scholarship but also famously nurtured distinctive schools of practice. Because the field of history, and the schools that comprise it, are under the control of a professional community of historians, the information structure that grounds a historical database will reflect a necessarily partial (and perhaps even political) set of interests. In other words, can there be any kind of database other than a politicized database? (And what, in any case, would be the effect of bringing physicists themselves who are usually excluded from writing the formal histories of their field into the company of those who oversee the NSLS Digital Archive?)

Discussions of dominant ‘symbolic forms’ in the digital age have often focused on the so-called ‘dyad’ of narrative and database. The origin of this discourse is Lev Manovich’s classic, The Language of New Media, where Manovich (2001) describes database and narrative as opponents, with database superseding narrative, in the digital age, as the dominant cultural form. Responding to Manovich, Hayles (2007, 2012)—while supporting the claim that database and narrative are ‘different species’—has persuasively argued that they act not as enemies but as symbionts. The unordered structure of the database gives us new tools for finding patterns in masses of information, but after we have done the work of finding patterns, we use narrative to give those patterns meaningful forms, such as argument or cause and effect. Moreover, we use the narratives (which includes the implicit hierarchies) of our disciplines to determine how to generate, collect, and categorize the data in our databases. (In Gitelman’s (2013) memorable phrase, ‘Raw data is an oxymoron’.)

The relatively new genre of the historical database thus presents a special instance of the contemporary challenge, in media scholarship, of reconciling narrative with database—specially because our response to it directly affects the design of our knowledge platforms. Does the involvement of human agents in creating or managing a database limit or predetermine the uses that will be made of its contents? In short, yes: while the structure of a database evades traditional narrative elements such as sequence and fixed order, a database designed by and for historians will still capitulate to ‘narrative’ in the sense of the embedded logics of the discipline. But this very feature is a part of what makes a historical database, as an artifact, evaluable as a contribution to the discipline—which allows us to treat this inevitability as an opportunity. If database thinking entails thinking in terms of classifications and relationships, then the integration of database thinking with historiographic thinking represents not an end of theory nor (in a term that was famously applied prematurely to our postmodern technological society) an end of history,5 but rather an extension of the historiographic tradition into the materially grounded, practice-based domain that Ratto (2011) has called ‘critical making’.

Ultimately, the importance that humanists ascribe to reconciling narrative with database reflects the fact that humanists depend on narrative not only for their materials but also for their practice. One feature that separates the sciences from the humanities is that while the scientist’s methods can be paraphrased without any loss, in the humanities the description is understood to be a part of the method. Geertz (1973) captured an aspect of this practice in the phrase ‘thick description’, referring to the careful negotiation of the researcher’s frameworks of observation. As research objects in the digital humanities become more complex, we have a growing need to articulate principles for the design of digital infrastructures to support the management of new volumes and configurations of data relevant to humanists. Here, too, the deliberate negotiation of frameworks persists, albeit at layers that are sometimes invisible to the user. Call it deep description.

We might describe the primary danger, from a historian’s perspective, of the hidden filtering implemented by deep description in terms of the problem of narrative lock. Narrative lock refers to the danger of constructing a database in such a way that it already embeds narratives—or at least because some measure of prearrangement is inevitable in database design, the danger of doing so unreflectively. It would be easy, for instance, to set up a database about the NSLS research in which the main things tracked would be factors such as the flow of money, the generation of publications, or the awarding of prizes, as if these were the only obvious factors of interest in research. Such a database can have valuable uses; an existing example is the US DOE’s database of information regarding user projects at its Office of Science User Facilities, which can reveal which users in a particular congressional district have used a particular DOE user facility. The kind of database we aim to create, however, should not predetermine the narratives that emerge from it, but rather should allow new narratives to be spotted and created. Ideally, such a database should be as amenable to surprising the researcher as an oral interview, where something unexpected may surface that is of value to the prepared investigator.
Special strategies must be used to avoid this danger. The three strategies that seem most necessary to us are flexible and expansive classification, transparency, and alterability.

1. The first strategy involves a flexible and expansive classification scheme. We need to choose a set of guiding organizational principles for the relations and attributes in the database that has sufficient flexibility to encompass the richness of the work in the New Big Science. This is an area in which the domain expertise of the historian can play a strong role. Just as the designer of a relational database for an organization must interview members of the organization in order to understand their information needs, thus gaining a detailed understanding of the ‘mind’ of the organization, the designer of a historical database can bring his knowledge of the material to bear on the creation of definitions.

For example, consider the question of experiments and research activity. How can we classify an experiment for the purpose of supporting a rich array of attributes and relationships? We can find an expansive organizational principle in the notion of performance; that is, treating the key research activity staged in the experimental hall around the machine as performances.

Treating experiments as performances is a useful way to broaden our conception of what is significant in staging, interpreting, and evaluating them for use in a database. A performance has a wide range of features that have agency; for this reason, applying the concept of performance to our understanding of experiments in the new scientific ecosystem would allow the database to become more granular than would traditional scientific categories, moving beyond tracking simple features such as collaborators, instruments, results, and publications. The various dimensions of performance—the actors, the props, the funding, the scripts, the audience, the reviews, the sequels, the techniques, the managers, the ‘theatre’ provided by the machine itself, the management of the theatre, the connections to other performances—can help us to generate a set of entities and attributes in a flexible and expansive way. The concepts of performance can help us to identify the components to be used in structuring the database in a way that avoids many traditional assumptions about scientific practice, especially in the context of the New Big Science. These traditional assumptions can predetermine how the entities and attributes are seen to hang together, as for instance in actor–network theory, which cannot see ecologies but only boundaries and negotiations. The activity of performance, by contrast, is not a negotiation, not a trading-off of interests. Rather, it involves a constant adaptation to a continually changing situation: audience, stage, props, co-performers, mistakes, and so forth. Treating research as a performance not only provides a wider and more flexible range of entities and but also attributes for a database. The fact that many different sorts of factors enter in a performance already puts the inquirer in the position of not having a ‘right’ way of synthesizing data, weakening traditional conceptions, and helping to ensure that any act of bringing data together is creative.

To be clear, we have not chosen the concept of performance as an organizing principle for designing the NSLS digital archive simply because it produces more granular data. The concept reflects the domain expertise of the historian; it has been brought to bear on historical thinking about scientific activity outside the field of database design, and as such represents an intrinsic, not extrinsic, intervention in digital historical research. The word performance has a broad spectrum of meanings, but one meaning that has special relevance for our purposes is the conception, production, and witnessing of material events which give back something more than was put into it. That is, you plan the experiment, you understand all the elements that go into it—the materials, the instruments, the theories or programming of the experiment—and yet, when the performance takes place, you get something that is more than all these elements, something you could not get by reading books or talking to people. In this sense, performance is not a suggestive metaphor carried over from the performing arts into scientific inquiry but rather a true descriptive term (Crease 1993). Performances are not events whose outcomes we already know. (If we already know the outcome, it is a demonstration, not a performance.) Performances aim to uncover more than what we know; performances leave the inquiry in a different place. For example, an experiment that has been planned and structured based on a certain theory can cause the experimenters to revise the theory, and use these revisions in subsequent experimental performances.

Still, the value of performance for our discussion here is its potential to heighten the utility of our database design by supplying an expansive classification scheme. The choice of a classification scheme is not without consequences, however.6 In this case, the concept brings to light what we might call the role of ‘staging’ in materials science research; that is, it points to a new research paradigm. The stages—theaters, if you will—of modern materials science strongly affect what can be done and even why it is being done. This is a new development in the history of science that historians and policy makers need to consider, and this kind of database brings it to light. (The staging of an experiment can even have political implications and consequences—as in SESAME, a synchrotron source that is being built in the Middle East, with collaborating scientists from members, such as Israel and the Palestinian Authority, that do not formally recognize the other's existence.) This approach would treat the database as an analog not to a book but rather to a journal such as Annales or Representations, which not only curate scholarship but have also nurtured distinctive schools of practice. Because the field of history, and the schools that comprise it, are under the control of a professional community of historians, the information structure that grounds a historical database will reflect a necessarily partial (and even political) set of interests. It may be true, owing to the place, in database creation, of narratives arising from domain expertise, that there can be no kind of database other than a politicized database; but we can at least mitigate the dangers of this condition by foregrounding it as a self-conscious practice.

2. The second strategy has to do with transparency. One of the major sources of narrative lock, as scholars such as Wardrip-Fruin (2009) have discussed, results from the structure of the database being hidden from users. By making the rules and structures clear that govern the database at the outset, we hope to be able to encourage the production of new narratives that we have not thought of. People can work around the constraints of a database more easily if they know what those constraints are.

3. The third strategy is to allow and facilitate alterations in the structure and classifications. The issue of narrative lock is an old one; humanists have known for centuries that (for instance) our words already influence what we think and say, and our tools already shape what we can build. This is not a problem that can—or should—be eradicated. Scholarship has few Athenas that spring forth fully formed; the emergence of new ideas, of new stories, always appears from the vestiges of the old. (As Wittgenstein once wrote, ‘My account will be hard to follow: because it says something new but still has eggshells from the old view sticking to it’.) Databases, too, wear ‘eggshells’ in the form of organizing principles. The goal of a database designer who works on behalf of the humanities is to make the shells strong enough to allow the emerging story to be told, but weak enough to be broken so that more new ones can be formed.

In this article, we have focused on some of the more pressing questions that digital projects of this kind elicit. As we design new platforms for managing historical data about complex research artifacts, what can we suggest about the design principles that will support diverse and flexible use? How do the constraints that accompany digital forms of production challenge us to rethink the role of constraint in historical analysis? What is the relationship between the ordering and anti-ordering impulses of narrative, interface, and database? In this era of big data, huge international collaborations, less visible scientific activities and infrastructure, it is more critical than ever to create new models and tools to support a new kind of history of science. If we wish for historians to explore large-scale science in a way that they have not been able to do before; for the general public to easily explore openly available government data in order to improve the public understanding of science; and for government officials to better understand what happens to the money spent on individual research projects, then we need to find ways to consolidate the history of such facilities and make the data of that history available for scholars and other users to work with more easily. Without doubt, the triumph of invisible knowledge infrastructures—the deep structure of databases rather than the visible structure of card catalogues and library classification systems—will dramatically change our methods of knowledge management in the humanities. But we will not have lost the need for humanistic approaches to knowledge management until we have ceased to reason using analogy, narrative, and metaphor.

Some very simple databases have been created to show links between facilities and researchers which do in fact simply regurgitate existing information. One example is a 2013 database that the DOE developed to connect researchers in congressional districts with facilities in other districts.
For a recent critical response to this subject, see Liu (2008).

Indeed, any classification scheme that a historian may choose will be in tension with the classification schemes that researchers, technicians, and administrators at the NSLS used to direct and record their own work, unless he uncritically mimics their classifications. The records that supply the bulk of the data for the project—annual reports, presentations to administrative review panels, records of publications, and so forth—were compiled by scientists and administrators. As such, their structure is meant to be invisible; their design, which formats and displays data for easy retrieval, identifies them as “legacy” databases.
